newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Nicaragua pledges to back Taiwan's U.N. bid.
newsitem.headline: Nicaragua pledges to back Taiwan's U.N. bid.

text.p: Nicaragua, one of the 30 states that recognise Taipei instead of its arch-rival Beijing, on Saturday pledged to support Taipei's bid to join the United Nations.

"The Republic of China is a free, democratic sovereign nation, it deserves to be given proper recognition by the world," visiting Nicaraguan President Arnoldo Aleman, through a translator, told reporters before ending his five-day state visit.
"Nicaragua will never change its firm support for the Republic of China's participation in the United Nations and other international organisations," Aleman said.
Taipei and Beijing have been arch-rivals since a civil war split them in 1949.

Beijing, which views the island as a renegade province and reacts fiercely to any move to recognise or seat Taiwan, took over China's U.N. seat in 1971 when Taipei was expelled from the United Nations.

In exchange for Nicaragua's backing, Taiwan would offer technical assistance and other cooperation to help Nicaragua's development, a joint communique signed by Aleman and Taiwan President Lee Teng-hui said.
Lee has accepted Aleman's invitation to visit Nicaragua, but no exact date has been set.
Aleman's visit was closely followed by a similar visit by Costa Rican President Jose Maria Figueres, who was scheduled to arrive in Taiwan late on Saturday.
Costa Rica, Nicaragua and a handful of other countries recently proposed a discussion on granting Taiwan U.N. membership during a General Assembly session in September.
China had prevented similar proposals from winning inscription on the U.N. agenda for four consecutive years.
President Lee would embark on a two-week tour to central American nations in September.

Lee in 1995 made a private, but high-profile visit to the United States that prompted an angry Beijing to launch months of intimidatory war games and unarmed missile tests near Taiwan to warn the island against independence.
